title: Doctor-in-the-Loop: An Explainable, Multi-View Deep Learning Framework for Predicting Pathological Response in Non-Small Cell Lung Cancer
author: Alice Natalina Caragliano (Università Campus Bio-Medico di Roma), Filippo Ruffini (Università Campus Bio-Medico di Roma), Carlo Greco (Università Campus Bio-Medico di Roma), Edy Ippolito (Università Campus Bio-Medico di Roma), Michele Fiore (Università Campus Bio-Medico di Roma), Claudia Tacconi (Università Campus Bio-Medico di Roma), Lorenzo Nidi (Fondazione Policlinico Universitario Campus Bio-Medico), ..., Valerio Guarrasi (Università Campus Bio-Medico di Roma)
background: This study aims to predict the pathological response in non-small cell lung cancer patients by integrating expert knowledge into a deep learning framework to enhance both prediction accuracy and explainability.
contribution: This paper introduces the Doctor-in-the-Loop framework to solve the challenge of predicting pathological responses in cancer patients, achieving higher predictive performance and explainability.

technical_comparison.prior_work: Previous methods used deep learning with either post-hoc explainability or lacked integration of clinical knowledge during training.
technical_comparison.novelty: This work improves by incorporating expert-driven domain knowledge directly into the model training, ensuring a clinically relevant focus during learning.

key_innovation: The framework combines domain expertise with a gradual multi-view approach, allowing the model to focus on both broad anatomical regions and specific lesions.
real_world_impact: By enhancing explainability in predictions, this framework can facilitate trust among clinicians, ultimately improving decision-making in cancer treatment strategies.

new_terms.Doctor-in-the-Loop: **Doctor-in-the-Loop** is a machine learning framework that involves integration of expert clinical knowledge into the training and prediction processes to ensure relevance and interpretability of the model's focus.
